column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Mardi Himal
#Text=The Mardi Himal trek is in the Annapurna region of Nepal .

#Text=For information on preparing for this trek , including when to go , what to bring , what permits are required , and safety precautions including altitude sickness , and water contamination , see Trekking in Nepal .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Mardi Himal is a lesser known trek that runs along the ridge just east of the popular Annapurna Sanctuary trek to Mardi Himal Base Camp .

#Text=From high on the ridge , the trail provides panoramic views of the Annapurna range , Machhapuchhre ( Fish Tail ) and Mardi Himal as well as sweeping vistas of the Himalaya foothills and cities of Ghandruk , Chomrong and Pokhara .
#Text=While the route has been used by self-supported groups for many years , it was officially opened in 2012 with the addition of lodges that provide food and accommodation .
#Text=Compared to nearby treks , it is less busy , shorter , and has a more consistent ascent to its maximum elevation of .
#Text=The trek can be comfortably completed in 5-6 days including transport to and from Pokhara although most trekking companies advertise an 8 day itinerary out of Kathmandu .
#Text=The increased popularity of the trek has led to an accommodation shortage at peak times .
#Text=In response , may tea houses have set up tents to accommodate the overflow .
#Text=If you wish to be sure of securing a room either call to reserve or arrive early in the day .
#Text=Most lodges have gas showers and lights provided by solar power , although some have backup generators .
#Text=Prices are fixed and regulated by a committee so they should be the same for all lodges at a single location .
#Text=Get in
#Text=There are several options to access the start of the trek .
#Text=From Pokhara , most trekkers take a bus to Kande , although it 's also possible to start from Phedi .
#Text=Buses depart from the Baglung bus station .
#Text=From the Annapurna Sanctuary Trek , take the trail to Landruk via New Bridge .
#Text=To Forest Camp
#Text=There are several options depending on where you are starting .
#Text=Kade to Deurali
#Text=From Kande , climb to Australian Camp , 1-1.5 hr and then descend slightly to Pothana before continuing on to Deurali .
#Text=Deurali to Forest Camp
#Text=, 4-5 hr
#Text=Make a right turn at the Forest Camp signpost at Deurali and follow the trail through jungle along the top of the ridge .
#Text=From Landruk
#Text=Be prepared for a gruelling climb on a south-facing aspect that will leave you sweating and gasping for air .
#Text=This is a less frequented trail that gives good views of Ghandruk , Annapurna South and down the valley to Nayapul for the first half of the climb .
#Text=From the jeep stand , follow the trail into Upper Landruk , turning left at the marker and following the pained blue and white trail markers north out of town .
#Text=The trail climbs up steep switch-backing turns , alternating between roots , rocks and steps .
#Text=After about there is a viewpoint on the left that has good views of Annapurna .
#Text=After this point the trail is more in the trees so it is a good place to stop for a break .
#Text=In the last few hundred meters before connecting with the main trail to Forest Camp , the trail is somewhat exposed to falls due to a landslide .
#Text=Forest Camp to Low Camp
#Text=Out of Forest Camp , the trail climbs gradually and heads to the right , skirting a high point on the ridge .
#Text=As the forest thins , there are glimpses of a view to the south-east and Pokera .
#Text=After 25-45 min , arrive in Rest Camp and enjoy the first close-up view of Machhapuchhre .
#Text=The trail travels through rhododendron forests as it continues to Low Camp .
#Text=In the last the trail levels out and you may encounter yaks .
#Text=Low Camp to High Camp
#Text=Immediately out of Low camp , the trail is up to one meter below ground level due to wear and erosion .
#Text=In this section , loose rocks may make footing tricky .
#Text=Route finding can be difficult at times as the erosion has created several apparent paths .
#Text=After climbing out of the heavily eroded section , stay left and gain the ridge .
#Text=Once on the ridge , the trail fragments again .
#Text=Keep your eyes open for the blue and white trail markers pained on trees and as long as you keep heading uphill you ca n't get too far off course .
#Text=At Mid Camp , pass a single guest house and continue up the ridge to Lower High Camp where the trail permanently breaks from the trees giving panoramic views .
#Text=High Camp is reached following the undulating ridge-top .
#Text=High Camp to MBC
#Text=, 3-5 hr ( one way )
#Text=As there is no accommodation past High Camp , most people make a return day trip up to Mardi Himal Base Camp ( MBC ) .
#Text=There are several destinations along the ridge , Lower View Point , 1.5-2.5 hr ; Upper View Point , 2.5-3 hr ; MBC , 3.5-4 hr ; and Upper MBC , 4-6 hr .
#Text=It is a popular option to stat walking in the dark to reach the Lower Viewpoint and beyond for sunrise .
#Text=There are tea houses at Lower and Upper Viewpoints , but they are quite expensive ( Milk Tea Rs . 300 ) so consider packing snacks and water .
#Text=After leaving High Camp , descend slightly into a saddle .
#Text=From here the trail forks , the left route is a steep but short climb up a rise that may make those afraid of heights uncomfortable .
#Text=The right fork is a circuitous route that has an easier grade an no exposure to falls .
#Text=After Lower Viewpoint
#Text=the grade noticeably mellows and it is a fairly easy walk ( except for the elevation ) to Upper Viewpoint and MBC .
#Text=The more adventurous may wish to continue beyond MBC to Upper MBC which is higher .
#Text=The trail is steep and difficult to follow in sections so trekkers should have alpine experience and rudimentary route finding abilities .
#Text=Follow the trail to the right across the rocky slope and cross the slide path .
#Text=As you reach the first shoulder you have the option to follow a faint trail up the ridge directly above you , or continue east to the next ridge and follow it to the summit .
#Text=From Upper MBC you 'll enjoy spectacular views towards Annapurna I , Machhapuchhre , Mardi Himal and south along the trail .
